title: Industrial Design Student Work: Therapeutic Eyewear
description: This Sooze project is by Maoxin Yuan, done while studying Industrial Design at Australia's UNSW Sydney. Yuan tackled a degenerative eye disease:"Keratoconus is a progressive eye disease that leads to thinning and protrusion of the cornea. It further results in irregular astigmatism and serious eye discomfort."Sooze provides comfort and vision support for keratoconus patients through a modular system of a neural stimulating headband and detachable visor module." "The visor module and the light engine in the headband work together to capture and deliver clear images directly to patients' retinas, regardless of their cornea shape. The electrode on the headband sends low-intensity electricity to the patient's upper eye and forehead area through a conductive textile strap, increasing patients' tear production and easing their eye pain when they are awake and asleep. The light engine emits red light at night when the visor is off, further improving keratoconus patients' sleep quality." Yuan's project won him an Australian Graduate of the Year Award.
author: Rain Noe

title: Nike's 3D-Printed Air Max 1000s
description: This past weekend at ComplexCon in Las Vegas, Nike unveiled their 3D-printed Air Max 1000. The kicks were created in collaboration with Zellerfeld, a German manufacturer of 3D-printed footwear. Zellerfeld's process means you can create different densities of cushioning in different parts of the shoe as shown below, with a non-Nike example: Nike Chief Innovation Officer John Hoke calls the production method of the Air Max 1000s as "control, times precision, times expression — all of which are vital to sport and to design." That said, as with a concept car, no production plans have been announced.
author: Rain Noe

title: How to Make Fluffy DIY Christmas Bows
description: How to make EASY Christmas bows for your holiday decor! Simple instructions to make fluffy DIY bows, from small to big, for your Christmas decorations.  I searched for "easy Christmas DIY bows" a few years ago and tried at least three versions (that seemed incredibly easy).  Each time I ended up with a mess of ribbon that looked NOTHING like what they showed.  I finally found a simple bow that ended up looking pretty cute, so I wanted to share the easy steps! You only need two things for this quick tutorial -- wired ribbon (I think I had 30 yards) and wire of some kind. You can use wire, floral wire, pipe cleaners...anything like that will work.  1. Cut your ribbon to long lengths First up, cut one long piece of ribbon at around five feet (I ended up making them a bit longer, around 65 inches) and a shorter piece at two feet.  You'll see the size of the bows with these measurements in this post -- adjust the lengths to your liking!  Then place the long one on a surface like so: src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEisgxUQ7mMJs_cmJWuWHiPUMsqqTkWyZNkwb53FA5W2kba1P9NMQJ6y7wZE1Zm2luxzVeOQt7euTP45wif3IYS3VnqZ2mfqE7z9LcaT76x4DQUpRCnmLI1tvOQa_tpuUB8p6SyTNLLe5AQ/s16000/IMG_9870.jpg"> This post may contain affiliate links for your convenience. I may earn a small commission when you make a purchase through links.  See my policies and disclosure page for more information.     Using wired ribbon will make this much easier -- it keeps its shape as you go.  I had to study the photo as I did this because I kept doing it backwards. You just lay it flat and then pull one side over, then the other.  You may want to widen that part at the top as you go, that will be the back part of the bow. 2. Make your ribbon loops Then, take the smaller section of ribbon and overlap the ends a bit like so: Read the full postThis content is property of Thrifty Decor Chick LLC. title: How to Install DIY Panel Molding and Wall Trim
description: How to add a DIY library paneling molding look to your walls. Install your own wall molding (and save a ton!) that gives you that classic library/dark academia look.  Last I left you on my office makeover, I had installed the peel and stick wallpaper, removed and installed the new baseboards, installed the chair rail and given everything a couple coats of paint:  src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh4jopEj9wjsj8HIOO-PsOATH1_DeXdnazTqWXszpIRT9mzlEkoAd4U4kpN-quAQy5Wv-4uryzulNakpXykBGMSejOLM9WymhYMXCMyFDfQkWFuaamzm-Kzxje7JnlMXHz2SEzkoAAWNQzymFPTM6hrSyHcWOU-8T05rxlIGgs1JmGXkNA2GlWUswKz67U/s16000/green%20trim%20grasscloth%20wallpaper.jpg"> That pretty green paint color is called Vintage Vogue -- it's a Benjamin Moore color, but I have it mixed at Sherwin-Williams.  You can read all about that process and the grasscloth wallpaper I used here.  After that, I stalled out on the DIY stuff (because: marching band season) till recently. My goal for the lower third of the wall was to create a library paneling type of look.  There are so many ways to add character to your walls with molding. For this room, I wanted it to be a simple but beefy look that adds some detail to this room.  Step One: Deciding on your design I ended up doing a classic look using two pieces of molding. Simple, primed one by twos and this cove trim:  src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgcCKs_avyABffKvSfWkDZvlCWipvBV24wLWD5pfxSt9Go5dL_9kLZ3TEN2qlCn2nPy3U5cbxJ-KhBSBWdaxsZIsDunSiY5NoS0069uK8X9elU1QtcIrBHoJXYNv3huFCt6XUs77fpZD5HbWKSPycPnsKeCLq9HY8TKGfxCAAnFUEW_dEnqPWNkCv8fn5w/s16000/vinyl%20curved%20molding.jpg"> This post may contain affiliate links for your convenience. I may earn a small commission when you make a purchase through links.  See my policies and disclosure page for more information.    When those curved pieces are placed on each side, it really makes that thin 1x2 feel much more substantial: src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjivUqajw5lmCvq4r8o6Ch1EWOgKxj0Z0BqVROiElip7e75nxGY5hyphenhyphensgcjTQe07sXXhonU9mv0E8oRuU5y_Yg09bfu-n4D_WFyHsaAbGma5eEiEeznqdbZHZ9UBR0vAnYfb20mERrSlRs3QYmkrZKOeq5QL-Km8hCLw0o7086JuxAZ8TLTVnPBvA8kNuus/s16000/DIY%20library%20paneling.jpg"> The curved molding is actually a paintable vinyl product that is great for outside and in bathrooms. I like that it's lightweight, easy to cut and cheaper than wood.  I had already added the curved trim to the top of the chair rail. Usually I would go with a simple 1x2, but I really like how this turned out with that coved look on top and bottom of each piece of trim.  Before I got started, I needed to fix some gaping in the baseboards and chair rail. It was only bad along the long wall in the room: Read the full postThis content is property of Thrifty Decor Chick LLC. title: A Revived 1850s Inner-City Cottage With A Generous Green Roof
description: Nest Architects completed their first residential project — a renovation of an inner-city Melbourne cottage with a thriving new green roof — in 2011, serving as a case study on how to create small and sustainable family homes. The project continues to inspire clients today, including the owners of this Richmond cottage, who came to Nest seeking a similar design solution. Working on a relatively limited budget, Nest managed to increase the size of their home while improving its liveability. The cherry on top is the green roof, which features 19 different plant species, and insulates the house while providing habitat for local wildlife!
author: The Design Files

title: A Tiny Pre-War Cottage Transformed Into A Low-Maintenance Entertainer’s Delight
description: Originally built in the early 1900s, this tiny Brisbane home had seen better days when it was first snapped up by a couple of young students more than 10 years ago. Now, thanks to an extensive renovation by architects Lineburg Wang, the once dilapidated cottage boasts a serene open-plan extension with a minimalist kitchen and living area (and a DJ booth overhead!) that flows into an airy courtyard. Despite the size of the 239-square-metre block, the project maximises on space and ensures comfortable, low-maintenance living for the young family.
author: The Design Files

title: What Is Scandifornian Style and How to Bring It Into Your Home
description: Scandifornian design is quickly becoming a favorite among homeowners and decorators. This trend marries the minimalism of Scandinavian design with the laid-back, sunny vibes of California. The result? Spaces that feel light, airy, and effortlessly inviting. title: Downsizing Update: Almost 5 Years Later
description: In November of 2020, we published a post called “What’s It Like To Downsize” after living in our smaller home for 6 months. We covered a range of experiences – like the good things about moving to a smaller home (owning less stuff! saving money!) and some of its challenges, especially in the initial stages of downsizing (paring down! figuring out storage!). We still agree with everything in that post, but it had only been six months… and since it has now been over 4.5 years (!!!), we feel like we have a few more to add about the long-haul downsizing experience. Let’s get into it. I won’t recap our entire decision to downsize (you can see the full explanation here) but the highlights are: We used to live in a 3,150 sq. ft. home in suburban Richmond, Virginia Now we live in a 1,400 sq. Continue reading Downsizing Update: Almost 5 Years Later at Young House Love.
author: John Petersik

title: A Girls Weekend In Sedona, Arizona
description: My best friend and I live in different parts of the country (we’ve been best friends for 24 years, and have only spent about 1/3 of them in the same city), so we love taking trips together. Let me tell you, the joy of packing light (only for yourself! not the whole fam!) and having a few nights of sleepovers in a fun new place and exploring so freely (just us eating dessert for breakfast if we want to!)… it’s euphoric. And our latest trip that we enjoyed was a completely new spot for me! She grew up going to Sedona with her family, but I had never been! She didn’t have to work hard to sell me on it though – the gorgeous views, the warm temperatures, magical mystical vortexes, shops full of crystals, and this pool? Sold! Where We Stayed In Sedona We splurged to stay at Enchantment Resort, which is a resort that my best friend has always wanted to experience. Continue reading A Girls Weekend In Sedona, Arizona at Young House Love.
author: Sherry Petersik

title: Jaime Hayon Goes Bestial at His Miami Art Show
description: Opening in December at Mindy Solomon Gallery in Miami during Art Basel Miami Beach, Jaime Hayon’s solo exhibition “Bestial” immerses visitors into the Spanish artist and designer’s exuberant, highly imaginative universe through a collection of new paintings and sculptures.

title: Nightingale Restaurant: A Modern Take on Viennese Coffee House Culture in London
description: Located in a secluded Mayfair courtyard, Nightingale, a new all-day restaurant designed by Tutto Bene—the London and Milan-based studio led by Felizia Berchtold and Oskar Kohnen—is a poetic blend of classic European aesthetic and contemporary design.
